route.name: The Fractured Canvas
route.subtitle: A journey through painted realities
route.description: Follow Verso's path through shadowed corridors and painted realities. Navigate the threshold between worlds and uncover the secrets of the Canvas Ghost.

nodes.title: Rain and Remembrance
nodes.text:
Rain hits the stone in uneven rhythms. Half your hand is flesh. Half is pigment—layered oils that shift between ochre and umber with each pulse of your uncertain heart.

Lumière sprawls before you, but it's wrong. The architecture remembers a different city, rebuilt in someone else's memory. The café where you met Aline stands three stories taller. The fountain in the square runs backwards.

You shouldn't be here. The Paintress took you both during Expedition 33. Yet here you stand, neither fully real nor entirely painted.

choices.label: Examine your hand more closely. Understand what you've become.
Step into the backwards fountain square. Someone might be waiting.
Go to the café. Find where Aline's memory still lives.

nodes.title: Between States
nodes.text:
You hold your hand to the rain. Where flesh meets paint, there's no seam—just a gradual shift from one state to another. The painted portion doesn't get wet. The rain slides off it like oil on canvas.

You flex your fingers. The painted ones move with the same weight, the same resistance. You feel through them, but the sensation is… translated. Like reading emotion in a language you half-remember.

A figure appears at the corner of your vision. Tall, wrapped in cloth that might be shadow. It watches you the way curators watch paintings.

choices.label: Approach the figure. Demand answers.
Observe it from a distance. Learn before acting.
Move away quietly. This isn't your confrontation yet.

nodes.title: Reversed Waters
nodes.text:
The fountain pulls water upward, droplets climbing against gravity to disappear into a stone basin that shouldn't exist. You recognize the sculpture—La Fontaine des Souvenirs. But in the real Lumière, it was destroyed decades ago.

A child sits on the fountain's edge, legs swinging. She's entirely painted, her form shifting between brushstroke styles—impressionist one moment, hyperrealist the next. She notices you and smiles.

"You're like me," she says. "But older. Did you forget how to choose your style?"

choices.label: Sit beside her. Ask what she means.
Ask her about the fountain. Why it runs backwards.
This is wrong. Leave before she pulls you deeper.

nodes.title: Café of Ghosts
nodes.text:
The Café d'Or towers impossibly high, each added floor a different architectural period stacked like sediment. You enter through doors that remember your hands.

Inside, patrons sit frozen mid-conversation. Not still—frozen, caught between moments like insects in amber. Their coffee steams eternally. Their gestures hang incomplete.

At your usual table, a figure waits. She wears Aline's face, but her eyes are canvas-white, unpainted.

choices.label: Sit across from her. Face what the Paintress left behind.
Study the frozen patrons. Understand this place before engaging.
This is too much. Return to the square.

nodes.title: The Curator Speaks
nodes.text:
You stride toward the figure, rain forgotten. "What are you? What is this place?"

The figure regards you with something approximating amusement. When it speaks, its voice echoes from multiple directions.

"I am Renoir. I maintain the Gallery Between. You are Verso—a failed canvas that learned to walk." The cloth shifts, revealing eyes that spiral like oil in water. "The Paintress brought you here thirty-three expeditions ago. You've been walking through her unfinished paintings ever since."

"That's impossible. I remember—"

"You remember being painted to remember. Every thought you think, she thought first. But..." Renoir tilts its head. "You've changed. Somehow you're writing over her brushstrokes. Dangerous. Unprecedented."

choices.label: Tell me how to escape this place.
Who is the Paintress? What does she want?
If I'm a painting that walks, perhaps that's enough.

nodes.title: The Painted Child
nodes.text:
You sit beside the child, watching water defy nature. Up close, you see her edges blur and refocus constantly.

"I was painted to be someone's daughter," she says matter-of-factly. "But they forgot to paint parents. So I live here, where the fountain remembers everyone."

She points to the climbing water. "See? Each drop is a memory going home. The real city forgot this fountain, so it came here. The Painted Gallery keeps everything that reality throws away."

"How long have you been here?"

She shrugs, her shoulders dissolving into brushstrokes before resolidifying. "Time is different when you're made of paint. But I think... a long time. Long enough to see others like you arrive. Most don't stay. They either fade into the backgrounds or find doors out."

choices.label: Tell me about these doors. I need to find one.
You shouldn't be alone here. Come with me.
Thank her and move on. Some questions answer themselves.

nodes.title: Conversations with Absence
nodes.text:
You sit. The chair remembers your weight from a thousand previous meetings.

Not-Aline smiles with lips that have never held pigment. "You came. Part of me thought you'd run."

"You're not her."

"No. I'm what the Paintress painted when she tried to understand what your mother meant to you. But she got it wrong—painted me as something other than what I was." The canvas-eyes don't blink. "The real Aline is gone, Verso. She faded the moment Expedition 33 ended. I'm just... the confused sketch that remains. A mother filtered through the Paintress's warped understanding."

You feel a pang of grief. Even in death, even as a ghost, your mother is misunderstood.

Around you, the frozen café seems to lean in, listening.

"But," Not-Aline continues, "I remember things she never told her son. The Paintress pulled those memories from both of you before the end. Would you like to know them?"

choices.label: Yes. Tell me what I lost.
No. I won't let the Paintress shape my grief.
Why are you telling me this? What do you want?

nodes.title: The Price of Freedom
nodes.text:
Renoir's form ripples like heat shimmer. "Escape? You misunderstand your situation. You ARE the Gallery now. You're painted into its walls, woven into its logic. To leave would require unpaintingyourself. Becoming less than you are."

"There must be a way."

"There is," Renoir admits. "Find the Canvas Ghost. It exists between painted and real, neither and both. It knows doors that lead... elsewhere. But it extracts prices. Memory. Identity. Pieces of your soul transcribed into pigment."

The rain stops. In the sudden silence, you hear something distant—brushstrokes on canvas, impossibly loud.

"The Paintress is working again," Renoir says. "She's noticed you. That limits our time."

choices.label: Where can I find the Canvas Ghost?
Let her notice me. I'll confront her directly.
Help me hide. I need more time to understand.

nodes.title: The Mediator's Path
nodes.text:
Something shifts in Renoir's regard. "Acceptance. Unusual. Most fight their painted nature or drown in despair."

You look at your half-painted hand again. "I'm not what I was. Fighting that won't return the past. But perhaps... perhaps there's power in being both. Flesh and pigment. Real and imagined."

"A mediator," Renoir says softly. "One who exists in the threshold. That path has been walked before, though never by someone like you. The Canvas Ghost itself began as such a mediator."

The world around you seems to breathe, the painted city acknowledging your choice.

"If you truly walk this path," Renoir continues, "you must learn to paint reality as surely as the Paintress painted you. And you must learn to write truth into pigment, like the Writers of old. Neither Painter nor Writer, but something between."

The rain returns, but now you feel it on both flesh and painted skin equally.

choices.label: Teach me. I'll master this threshold.
I'll find my own way. Balance must be discovered, not taught.

nodes.title: Directions in Paint
nodes.text:
"The Canvas Ghost has no fixed location," Renoir explains. "It exists where painted and real overlap most completely. The café where memories freeze. The fountain where time flows backwards. The gallery where art breathes."

"You've seen such places already. The Ghost watches those who enter its territories. If you prove... interesting... it may appear to you."

Renoir gestures, and the rain around you crystallizes into shapes—maps written in water and light. "Go deeper into the Painted Gallery. Each threshold you cross will draw its attention. But be warned: the Canvas Ghost is not benevolent. It is curious. And its curiosity has destroyed greater souls than yours."

choices.label: I'll take the risk. Lead me deeper.
Perhaps confronting the Ghost isn't wise yet. I need to prepare.

nodes.title: Into the Threshold
nodes.text:
Renoir guides you through streets that fold like paper. Buildings peel away to reveal canvas beneath canvas, infinite layers of attempted realities.

You pass through a marketplace where vendors sell memories in jars. A library where books write themselves, their pages filled with stories that never happened. A bridge that spans the gap between yesterday and tomorrow.

With each step, you feel yourself changing. The painted portion of your body spreads slightly, but so does the flesh. You're becoming more of both, not less.

Finally, you reach a door. It's simple—wooden, unremarkable. But it stands alone in an empty plaza, connected to nothing.

"Beyond this," Renoir says, "is where the Canvas Ghost dwells. I cannot follow. This threshold is yours alone to cross."

You reach for the handle. It's warm under your half-painted fingers.

choices.label: Open the door. Face the Canvas Ghost.
Not yet. I'm not ready for what waits beyond.

nodes.title: Audience with the Ghost
nodes.text:
The door opens onto whiteness. Not empty—white. The white of fresh canvas stretched tight, waiting for the first brushstroke.

You step through.

The Canvas Ghost stands before you, if 'stands' is the right word. It's a figure composed of negative space, the absence of paint that defines all paintings. Where it moves, reality blurs and refocuses.

"Verso," it says without sound. "The painting that learned to bleed. The flesh that learned to fade. You stand at the perfect threshold."

Its form shifts—now humanoid, now abstract, now something between. "You seek escape from the Painted Gallery. But you are the Gallery. To leave would be to cease. Is that what you truly want? Or do you seek transformation? Evolution? To become something neither Painter nor Writer ever imagined?"

The whiteness around you pulses like a heartbeat.

choices.label: I choose transformation. Teach me to be both and neither.
I choose escape, whatever the cost. I'll be real again.
I reject both options. There must be another way.

nodes.text:
The Canvas Ghost's form stabilizes into something almost comprehensible. Its spiral eyes focus, its cloth-wrapped body solidifying into definite edges. "The threshold path. Difficult. Lonely. But perhaps the most honest."

It reaches out with appendages that might be hands, might be brushes, might be something that exists in the space between concepts. Where it touches you, flesh becomes paint becomes flesh again, cycling endlessly. The sensation is neither painful nor pleasant—it transcends such simple binaries. It simply is.

"You will walk between worlds now," the Ghost explains, and its voice carries harmonics from both the real world and the Gallery. "Neither trapped nor free. Neither real nor imagined. You will mediate between Painters who reshape reality and Writers who record truth. Your existence will be the bridge connecting what should never connect."

"What does that mean?" you ask, watching your hand cycle through states.

"It means you will understand both perspectives. When the Painters create impossibilities, you'll translate them into terms Writers can document. When Writers insist on singular truth, you'll show Painters how to ground their creations in it. You'll be the diplomatic channel between warring philosophies."

"And Aline?"

The Ghost's expression shifts—sadness rippling across its painted features. "The Paintress loves you in the only way she can: by making you more. But she'll never fully understand what it costs you. That's where you'll mediate—between her vision and your reality."

The whiteness fills your vision, overwhelming and absolute.

When it clears, you stand in Lumière again. The real Lumière—cars honk, people walk past speaking mundane French, the fountain runs clear and finite.

But you can still see the Painted Gallery overlaid on it like a translucent film. Two cities, one location. You exist in both.

The fountain is simultaneously normal water and liquid light. The café has two stories and infinite levels. People walk past you in the real world while painted figures drift through the Gallery space occupying the same coordinates.

Your hand is completely yours again—but it shifts between flesh and paint with each breath. When you pick up a coffee cup in the real world, you also paint brushstrokes in the Gallery. When you walk, you exist in both locations simultaneously.

You've become the threshold itself. The living doorway. The permanent bridge.

A Writer approaches you days later, frustrated. "The Painters claim Expedition 33 created seventeen different timelines. Which is true?"

A Painter approaches from the other direction, equally frustrated. "The Writers insist only one timeline exists. How can we create when they deny our realities?"

You touch the Writer with your right hand (flesh). You touch the Painter with your left (paint). And suddenly they understand each other. Not agreement—but genuine comprehension of opposing viewpoints.

"Oh," the Writer breathes. "You're documenting possibility. That's not the same as inventing falsehood."

"Oh," the Painter echoes. "You're creating grounded realities. That's not the same as denying imagination."

They nod to each other awkwardly and depart. You've mediated your first conflict.

More come. Writers who can't understand Painters. Painters baffled by Writers. People trapped between worlds, people torn by contradictory realities, people desperate for someone who speaks both languages.

You become their translator. Their bridge. Their threshold.

In the distance, you see both Renoir and the painted child waving from the Gallery. In another distance, you see the real city going about its day, unaware of the painted world that mirrors it. And you exist in both, eternally, necessarily.

Aline visits you in the cafe where real and painted overlap. She sits across from you, and for the first time, you see her clearly in both states—woman and Paintress, human and myth.

"Are you happy?" she asks. "I've made you into something unprecedented."

"I'm useful," you reply, watching your hand shift. "I've made peace with being neither one thing nor another. I'm the space between. That's enough."

She smiles, reaches across the table. Her hand (paint) takes yours (flesh-paint-flesh). The boundary between you blurs and clarifies simultaneously.

"You've become what I could never be," she says. "Truly balanced. I'm all Painter, all imagination. You're both—and that makes you more honest than either tradition alone."

You smile. For the first time since Expedition 33, you know exactly what you are: The Mediator. The Bridge. The living threshold between worlds that need each other but cannot touch directly.

Years pass. You never age normally—half of you is paint, immune to time. You exist, mediate, translate, bridge.

People come to you from across the fractured realities. You give them understanding. You help them see from multiple perspectives. You build connections where only division existed.

Your greatest work: convincing a council of Writers and a guild of Painters to actually collaborate. They create the first joint documentation-creation project—Scribes record an event while Painters imagine its implications across different timelines.

The result is revolutionary: layered truth. What happened (documented) and what could happen (painted), existing together without contradiction.

You facilitated that. You made them understand each other. You were the threshold through which both traditions could meet.

When you die—if you die, half-painted things don't age normally—they bury you at the exact point where the real Lumière and the Painted Gallery overlap most closely.

Your grave exists in both worlds. Real flowers and painted blooms grow on it simultaneously. Writers and Painters visit together, the only neutral ground they fully trust.

You spent your life as the bridge. Now you spend eternity as it.

The Mediator never fully belonged to either world. But you belonged perfectly to the space between them—and that space was exactly where you were needed most.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: The Mediator**
*You became the living bridge between real and painted, flesh and imagination, Writers and Painters. Your existence itself translated between worlds, making you the most essential diplomat in fractured reality.*

"Escape requires sacrifice," the Canvas Ghost says, its voice heavy with centuries of knowledge. "You must unpaint yourself. Strip away every brushstroke the Paintress added to your reality. You will forget the Gallery. Forget what you learned here. Forget who you met."

"I accept."

"Even," the Ghost continues, leaning closer, "if it means forgetting Aline entirely? Not just the Paintress, but all of her. The Paintress painted your memories of loving her into sharper focus, made them more vivid than organic memory ever could. Remove her work, and the real memories become unreachable. Locked behind doors you no longer have keys to. You'll forget you ever loved anyone named Aline."

You hesitate. The thought tears at you—losing her completely, not just the myth but the woman, the memories of laughter and coffee and quiet mornings.

But the Gallery is consuming you. Each day more of your flesh becomes paint. In a month, maybe less, you'll be entirely Gallery-bound, another painted figure unable to leave.

"I accept."

The Ghost nods slowly. "Then let us begin the unpainting. This will hurt. I'm sorry."

It reaches out, and where it touches your painted hand, you feel brushstrokes being pulled away. Not erased—removed, unstuck, peeled back.

It hurts. Oh god, it hurts. Each brushstroke removed is a small death, a piece of yourself being torn away. You feel yourself becoming less—less complex, less aware, less everything. Smaller. Dimmer. More mundane.

The painted portion of your hand fades first, revealing normal flesh underneath. But with it goes your ability to see painted colors that don't exist in the real spectrum. You lose senses you didn't know you had.

The memories go next. The fountain with infinite levels—blur. The café where you met the painted child—wash away like watercolors in rain. Renoir's kindness. The Canvas Ghost's wisdom. The sensation of existing in two states simultaneously.

Gone. All gone.

Aline goes last. The Ghost hesitates before removing those memories, its spiral eyes full of sadness. "Are you certain?"

"Do it," you whisper, tears streaming. "Before I change my mind."

It does. The brushstrokes that sharpened your memories of her peel away. And behind them... nothing. Just absence. The real memories are still there, technically, but they're so faint you can't reach them. Like trying to remember a dream hours after waking.

You know you loved someone. You think her name started with A. But the details are gone.

When it's done, you stand in regular Lumière. The real Lumière, fully and completely real.

The fountain runs normally, just water and physics. The café is exactly two stories tall as it should be. Cars honk. People argue in French. Everything is mundane and solid and absolutely real.

You remember coming here for... something. Expedition 33, maybe? You were part of that research team, weren't you? But the details are hazy. Something about fractures. Something about art.

Your hand is entirely flesh. You flex it experimentally. It works fine. Always has.

You should probably head home. It's getting late, and you have work tomorrow. Regular work. Normal work. The kind that doesn't involve impossible geometries or living paintings.

As you walk away toward the metro, you don't notice the figure watching from an alley—wrapped in cloth that might be shadow, its spiral eyes full of sadness and respect.

The Canvas Ghost watches you disappear into normal life. "Goodbye, Verso," it whispers. "You chose sanity over wonder. Perhaps that's the bravest choice of all."

You ride the metro home. Your apartment is small and real and yours. You make dinner. You watch TV. You go to bed.

In the morning, you wake with a strange sense of loss, like you've forgotten something important. But you can't remember what.

Days pass. Weeks. Months. The sense of absence fades. You meet someone new. Fall in love—or something like it. It's pleasant. Comfortable. Real.

But sometimes, walking past that fountain in Lumière, you pause. Feel something. An echo of significance that you can't quite place.

You never stay long. It makes you uncomfortable in a way you can't explain.

Years later, you're telling your partner about Expedition 33—the official story, the one that made the papers. "I was there when the fracture happened," you say. "But honestly, I don't remember much. I think the trauma made me block it out."

"That's normal," your partner says. "The mind protects itself."

You nod. The mind protects itself.

You live a full life. Normal. Real. Grounded in flesh and physics and provable facts. You have children. A career. Hobbies. Friends.

It's a good life.

But on quiet nights, you sometimes dream of colors that don't exist. Of fountains with infinite levels. Of someone you loved completely whose face you can no longer recall.

You wake up feeling empty, but by morning the feeling fades.

The mind protects itself.

When you die—old, surrounded by family, peacefully in your sleep—there's a figure at your funeral that no one else seems to notice. Wrapped in cloth, spiral-eyed, standing at the back.

As they lower your casket, it whispers: "You were painted once. You chose to be only real. You had the courage to give up wonder for sanity. Rest well, Verso. You earned the ordinary life you chose."

Your grave is entirely real. Just stone and earth. No painted flowers. No Gallery overlap. Exactly what you chose.

The figure stands there until sunset, then disappears into evening shadow.

You chose the real over the painted. You forgot what you were to reclaim what you had been. And perhaps—perhaps—that was the right choice.

The Gallery never forgets though. In the Painted Lumière, there's still a fountain where a child sometimes asks visiting figures: "Have you seen Verso? They used to come here. I miss them."

But in the real world, you're just another grave in a normal cemetery.

And that's exactly what you wanted.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: Return to Flesh**
*You chose to unpaint yourself completely, sacrificing all memories of the Gallery and Aline to reclaim ordinary reality. You lived a normal, grounded life—and died having forgotten you were ever anything more than human.*

"Neither transformation nor escape," you say firmly. "I reject the binary. You offer me two paths because you cannot imagine a third. But I'm already proof that the impossible happens. I'm flesh and paint, real and imagined. Why should I accept either/or when I'm already both/and?"

The Canvas Ghost makes a sound that might be laughter or might be awe. "Rebellion. How very... Writer of you. To insist on creating your own truth even when reality offers comfortable alternatives."

"And how very Painter of me," you counter, "to imagine a door that doesn't exist and walk through it anyway. You taught me that. Everything here was painted into existence by refusing to accept what was. Why should I accept what you offer?"

The whiteness around you cracks. Actually cracks, like dried paint on old canvas, like reality itself fragmenting.

"You're going to break the Gallery," the Ghost says, but it doesn't sound concerned. It sounds... delighted. "You're going to paint yourself new rules and write them into being. Synthesis through destruction. I should stop you."

"But you won't."

"No," the Ghost agrees, stepping back. "I want to see what happens. The Gallery has existed for centuries with the same rules. Maybe it's time someone broke them."

You reach into the white where it's cracking and pull. The canvas tears with a sound like ripping silk, like reality screaming. Beyond it is neither the Painted Gallery nor the real world—it's something else. Somewhere raw and undefined. Pure potential. Unpainted possibility.

You step through.

The Gallery shudders violently. You feel rules you don't yet understand rewriting themselves around your existence. You're still part flesh, part paint, but now you're also part... else. Part raw potential. Part becoming. Part the space between defined states.

You're walking through void. Not empty void—pregnant void, filled with unrealized possibilities. Every step forward, reality forms under your feet. Not painted. Not written. Something new. Something that synthesizes both traditions while belonging to neither.

Behind you, the Canvas Ghost watches through the tear. "The third door," it murmurs with something like pride. "Leading anywhere. Everywhere. Nowhere yet painted or written. Verso, the Impossible Made Walking."

You walk for what might be seconds or years. Time doesn't work here. Space doesn't work here. The normal rules are suspended in this undefined space you've torn yourself into.

You emerge... somewhere. A city that might be Lumière or might be somewhere entirely new. The buildings are neither painted nor real—they're something else. Self-authored. Real because you perceive them, painted because you imagine them.

People appear. Not painted figures. Not real humans. Something in between, like you.

They look at you with recognition. "You're the first," one says. "But not the last. You've shown us the third option."

You've created something unprecedented: a space that belongs to neither tradition. Not Gallery, not reality. A third state where flesh and paint merge into something entirely new.

Others follow you through the tear. People tired of choosing between real and painted, between written truth and painted possibility. They walk through the third door you've created and emerge transformed.

You become the First Walker—the one who refused the binary and created a third option through sheer refusal to accept limitations.

The Writers call you heretic. The Painters call you thief. But those caught between the traditions call you liberator.

You've proven that the impossible is just the unpainted, the unwritten—waiting for someone brave or foolish enough to step into undefined space and define it through existing in it.

You don't know where this new space will lead. You don't know what you're becoming. But for the first time since Expedition 33, that doesn't frighten you.

You're not trapped in the Gallery. You're not fleeing to mundane reality. You're walking your own path through spaces that don't exist until you imagine them into being.

The third door. Always open. Always undefined. Always becoming.

And you're walking through it forever, creating reality with each impossible step.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: The Third Door**
*You refused transformation and escape, instead tearing open a third option. You walked into undefined space and created new reality through sheer will—proving that binaries are illusions and impossible paths exist for those brave enough to walk them.*

nodes.title: Patient Observer
nodes.text:
You keep your distance, watching the curator from behind a pillar of uncertain architecture. Renoir moves through the rain without disturbing it—the drops part around its form like a painted river around stones.

It pauses at different points in the street, studying the buildings, the cobblestones, even the shadows. You realize it's inspecting them, maintaining them, like a curator checks the condition of artworks.

After some time, it speaks without turning toward you. "Observation is itself a kind of painting, Verso. To watch is to frame reality with your attention. You're learning already."

choices.label: Step out. Ask what it's maintaining.
Continue observing in silence.

nodes.title: The Silent Student
nodes.text:
You remain still, watching Renoir's methodical work. As you observe, you begin to see what it sees—the way certain buildings flicker between states, how shadows don't quite align with their sources, places where the painted world frays at its edges.

Renoir touches these imperfections, and they stabilize. Not through force but through... understanding? No, through acceptance. It allows them to be what they are, and in that allowance, they settle.

"You see it now," Renoir says. "The Gallery doesn't need perfection. It needs attention. Acknowledgment. Someone to witness its existence and say: you are real enough."

The rain stops. The city breathes.

choices.label: Let me help you maintain this place.
What happens if no one acknowledges the Gallery?

nodes.title: The Curator's Offer
nodes.text:
Renoir turns to face you fully for the first time. Its spiral eyes widen slightly—surprise?

"You would help maintain what imprisons you?"

"This isn't a prison," you realize as you speak. "It's a museum. A sanctuary for painted things. Someone needs to care for it."

Renoir is silent for a long moment. Then: "I have walked these streets for centuries. Alone. The Paintress creates, but she does not maintain. The Canvas Ghost observes, but does not tend. I am the only one who... cares."

It extends a cloth-wrapped appendage. "If you truly wish to learn, I will teach you. But know this: to become a curator is to choose the Gallery over escape. To dedicate yourself to preservation rather than freedom."

choices.label: I accept. Teach me to tend the painted world.
Let me see more of the Gallery first before I commit.

nodes.text:
You take Renoir's appendage—half hand, half brush, warm like sun-dried paint. The moment you touch, knowledge floods into you like pigment mixing with water.

Centuries of maintenance pour through the contact. Every tiny repair Renoir ever made, every loving attention to painted details, every patient smoothing of reality's rough edges. You see through its eyes—thousands of years of curating the impossible, of keeping painted reality stable enough to persist.

You learn to see the microscopic cracks where painted and real don't quite mesh—the seams showing, the brushstrokes fraying, the colors bleeding slightly out of their designated bounds. You learn to smooth them not through force but through presence, through gentle acknowledgment that allows them to settle.

You learn the patience of eternal curators, the devotion of those who preserve rather than create. The quiet satisfaction of maintenance, of making something last.

Days pass. Weeks. Time moves strangely when you're maintaining eternity—hours feel like minutes when you're absorbed in repairing a building's facade, years compress into moments when you're ensuring the rain continues its upward spiral.

Renoir grows fainter with each lesson, its substance transferring to you. "My time is ending," it says without sadness, its voice like wind through canvas. "I have waited so long for a successor. Centuries I've stood vigil alone. But you will be better than I ever was—you understand both sides of the canvas. You were flesh before you were paint."

"Where will you go?" you ask, feeling sorrow as its form becomes translucent.

"Nowhere. Everywhere. I will dissolve back into the Gallery itself, become part of what I've tended for so long. I will finally rest, knowing these streets, these buildings, these impossible geometries are in caring hands."

Renoir dissolves into the rain one evening, the last sunset of its existence painting the sky in colors that have no names. Its final words drift through the moisture: "Thank you. Be kind to them. They need kindness to persist."

Now you walk the streets alone, tending to the painted city with inherited devotion.

You smooth the rough edges where buildings flicker. You encourage bashful shadows back into place when they drift from their sources. You repair cobblestones that forget their solidity. You tend the fountain, ensuring the water's eternal climb remains smooth.

The Paintress creates new works, painting fresh impossibilities into existence. You maintain them, ensure they last, give them the stability to become real in their own way.

The Canvas Ghost observes from its liminal spaces, documenting the Gallery's evolution. You care for what it observes, making sure there's something worth documenting.

The painted child waves from the fountain daily. You ensure the water keeps climbing for her to play in.

You discover the quiet joy of preservation. The Paintress gets the glory of creation, but you have the satisfaction of continuity. Without you, her works would fade, fracture, dissolve. You make beauty last.

Years pass—or something like years. You don't age, being half-paint now. You simply are, eternally maintaining, eternally present.

New painted figures appear as the Paintress creates. You welcome them, teach them how the Gallery works, ensure they don't fade. You're their anchor, their stability.

You are complete. You are home. You are the Gallery's gentle keeper, and in keeping it, you find the purpose you never had in the real world.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: Renoir's Successor**
*You inherited centuries of curatorial knowledge and became the Gallery's eternal keeper. While the Paintress creates, you preserve—ensuring painted reality persists through patient, loving maintenance. You found home in eternal gentle care.*

nodes.title: Memories Flow Upward
nodes.text:
"Why backwards?" you ask, watching the impossible water.

The child kicks her legs thoughtfully. "It's not backwards. It's returning. In the real world, fountains send water down—memories flowing away, being forgotten. But here, everything that's forgotten comes back. The water climbs home."

She points to individual droplets. "That one is someone's first kiss. That one, their grandmother's lullaby. That one, the smell of bread from a bakery that burned down fifty years ago."

You watch the droplets climb and disappear into the stone basin. "Where do they go?"

"Into the Gallery's heart. The Paintress uses them to paint new things. Forgotten memories become new realities here."

choices.label: Reach out and touch the climbing water.
Tell me more about the Paintress. What is she?
Thank the child and move on.

nodes.title: Touching Forgotten Things
nodes.text:
Your fingers brush a climbing droplet. It bursts against your skin, and suddenly you remember:

A wedding that never happened. A child never born. A book never written. A song hummed once and never again. These aren't your memories—they're orphaned ones, belonging to no one and everyone.

They flood through you, hundreds of forgotten moments seeking a home. You stagger back from the fountain, overwhelmed.

The painted child catches your arm, steadying you. "Too many at once," she says gently. "You have to learn to filter them, or you'll become nothing but other people's forgetting."

But even as the flood recedes, some memories remain, woven into your painted portions like new brushstrokes.

choices.label: These memories are beautiful. I'll carry them.
These aren't mine. I need to let them go.

nodes.title: Bearer of the Forgotten
nodes.text:
You close your eyes and accept the memories. They settle into you, becoming part of your painted nature. You become a living gallery of forgotten moments—a walking memorial to everything reality lost.

The child smiles. "You're like the fountain now. A place where forgetting ends."

You feel different. Heavier, but not burdened. Fuller, but not overwhelmed. Each memory adds a new brushstroke to your form, making you more complex, more richly painted.

"The Paintress will be interested in you," the child says. "She's always looking for those who can hold multiple realities at once. Will you seek her out? Or will you keep collecting memories on your own?"

choices.label: Take me to the Paintress. Show me what I'm becoming.
I'll walk my own path, collecting what I find.

nodes.title: The Artist's Studio
nodes.text:
The child leads you through twisting streets to a tower that shouldn't exist. Its walls are canvas, stretched over frames of impossible geometry. You can hear brushstrokes from within—slow, deliberate, each one reshaping reality.

"She's working," the child whispers. "Be respectful. She doesn't like interruptions, but she'll like you. You're interesting."

You climb stairs that spiral in contradictory directions. At the top, a door of pure pigment. You push through.

The Paintress stands before an enormous canvas that shows the entire Painted Gallery. She's adding details to it—a new building here, a changed sky there. Each brushstroke creates reality below.

She doesn't turn, but she speaks. "Verso. The one who took my paint and made it bleed. Come closer. Let me see what you've become."

choices.label: Step forward. Let her examine you.
Why did you do this to me? To Aline?
Watch her paint before speaking.

nodes.title: Under the Artist's Gaze
nodes.text:
You approach, and the Paintress finally turns. She's stunning and terrible—her form constantly shifts between different artistic styles, as if she cannot decide which version of herself to be.

She cups your face with paint-stained hands, studying you like a masterpiece. "Fascinating. You're still changing. Most of my subjects settle into one state, but you... you remain in flux. Flesh becoming paint becoming flesh."

Her touch is warm. "I could stabilize you. Fix you into one perfect form. Or..." Her smile is enigmatic. "I could teach you to control the transformation. To paint yourself anew each day. Would you like to learn, Verso? To become an artist of your own existence?"

choices.label: Yes. Teach me to paint myself.
Teach me to paint reality itself, as you do.
I don't want your teachings. I want answers.

nodes.text:
The Paintress's eyes light up with something like joy—real joy, the first genuine emotion you've seen from her. "An apprentice. I haven't had one of those in... how long? Centuries? Millennia? Time is so fluid here."

She guides you to a smaller canvas, gesturing for you to sit. "Begin with something simple. Paint me a flower that has never existed."

You take the brush she offers. It feels right in your hand—both flesh and painted portions know how to hold it instinctively. The bristles hum with potential.

You paint. You don't know what you're doing, but your hand moves with confidence, mixing impossible colors, creating petals that fold in ways geometry shouldn't allow.

The flower blooms on the canvas, and simultaneously, you feel it bloom somewhere in the Gallery below—a new reality birthing itself. You've created something that now exists.

"Good," the Paintress says, and pride fills her voice. "Very good. You have the gift. Most painted beings can't create—they're too busy being created. But you...  you understand both sides. Now let me teach you everything."

Years pass—or moments, or eternities. Time means nothing when you're learning to reshape reality.

You learn to paint emotions into existence. You create joy as a yellow mist that makes people laugh when they walk through it. You paint sorrow as rain that makes beautiful music when it falls.

You learn to create entire districts of the Gallery with a few brushstrokes. A neighborhood springs from your canvas, complete with residents, histories, interconnected stories.

You learn to reshape painted beings, giving them new forms when they ask, new purposes when they feel lost. You become a sculptor of identity, an architect of possibility.

The Paintress watches your progress with pride and something else—relief? "Soon," she says, "you'll be ready to paint your own gallery. To create worlds as I do. You'll be a Painter in truth—no longer painted, but painting. Perhaps you'll succeed where I failed. Perhaps you'll learn balance."

"What do you mean, failed?"

She gestures at the Gallery. "Look at them. The painted beings. I created them, but I can't free them. I've become their mother and their prison. But you... you were human first. You understand freedom. Maybe you can create without trapping."

You look at your hands. They're entirely paint now, transformed fully through learning and practice. But paint that controls paint, art that creates art. You've transcended being creation—you've become creator.

Your first true creation, made without supervision: a painted memorial in the Gallery's garden. It honors your mother, capturing not her ghost but her memory—a woman flawed and brilliant, who loved through paint even when paint couldn't heal her demons. 

You don't paint her perfectly. You paint her honestly: the talent and the drinking, the brilliance and the neglect, the love expressed through canvas when words failed.

The Paintress studies it silently. "You've surpassed me already," she says quietly. "I could never paint truth and fiction together like this. Only one or the other."

You visit the memorial sometimes, not to change it, but to remember. A reminder of what you were before you learned to create, and who shaped you into what you've become.

Decades pass. You create seventeen new galleries, each with its own aesthetic, its own rules. The Paintress gives you autonomy—entire sections of painted reality belong to you now.

You paint beings who can leave if they choose. You create worlds with doors. You make beautiful prisons with unlocked gates.

Some stay. Some leave. That's the beauty of it.

The Paintress, ancient and tired, eventually asks you to take over fully. "I've been painting for too long," she admits. "I've forgotten why I started. But you... you still remember being human. You remember wanting freedom. You can do better."

You become the Paintress—or the Painter, gender irrelevant when you're made of pigment. You inherit the Gallery and reshape it slowly, gently, making it a place of wonder rather than imprisonment.

Your apprentices will ask you someday about the old Paintress, the one who created the first Gallery. You'll tell them about her brilliance and her limits, her vision and her blindness.

And you'll tell them about Aline, who loved you into painted reality, and about yourself, who learned to create without trapping.

That's the lesson you teach: create with open hands. Paint with love, not control. Make beauty that's free to leave.

Some does. Some stays. All of it matters.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: The Paintress's Apprentice**
*You became the Paintress's apprentice and learned to paint reality itself. Eventually you inherited the Gallery and reshaped it into a place of freedom rather than imprisonment—creating worlds with unlocked doors.*

nodes.title: Demanding Truth
nodes.text:
"Why did you do this?" Your voice is harsh, breaking the studio's reverent silence. "Why take us? Why paint us into this prison?"

The Paintress sets down her brush carefully. When she turns, her expression is unreadable.

"Prison? Is that what you call my masterpiece?" There's no anger in her voice, only curiosity. "I saved you, Verso. Expedition 33 was doomed. Everyone who entered those depths died—truly died, dissolved into probability and chaos. But you and Aline... you I painted. Preserved. Made eternal."

"Aline is a hollow ghost. I'm half-flesh, half-pigment, neither one thing nor another."

"You're alive," the Paintress counters. "In a way more permanent than flesh ever allows. Paint doesn't age. Doesn't decay. Doesn't forget. I gave you immortality."

"At what cost?"

choices.label: This isn't immortality. It's imprisonment. I'll stop you.
If you truly saved us, then free us. Prove it's not a prison.
Help me understand. Why do you paint people into existence?

nodes.title: Seeds of Rebellion
nodes.text:
You step back, putting distance between yourself and the Paintress. "You call this salvation, but it's tyranny. You create beings and trap them in your vision. No more."

The Paintress doesn't move to stop you as you turn and leave. Her voice follows you down the stairs: "Rebellion. How predictable. How... beautifully tragic. Very well, Verso. Rebel. See where it leads."

You return to the streets, your mind racing. If you're going to oppose the Paintress, you'll need allies. The painted child. Renoir. The frozen patrons in the café. Aline's ghost. All the painted beings trapped in her vision.

You can free them. You can lead them. You can overthrow the Paintress and create a Gallery where painted beings choose their own existence.

But first, you need to understand her power. And how to break it.

choices.label: Gather the painted beings. Build a revolution.
Learn her techniques. Use her own power against her.

nodes.text:
You move through the Gallery systematically, speaking to every painted being you find. Your message spreads like pigment bleeding through canvas.

The child at the fountain listens first. "Free?" she asks. "What does that even mean?"

"It means you choose. Not her. You."

She nods slowly, understanding dawning in her painted eyes.

The frozen café patrons—you learn to unfreeze them, one by one, speaking your truth as they gradually accelerate back to normal time. They listen. They agree. They're tired of being preserved in a single perfect moment.

Renoir listens with those spiral eyes, silent for long minutes. Finally nods. "I have tended her Garden for centuries. But you're right. Even caretakers deserve choice."

Even Aline's ghost, hollow and yearning, whispers yes with her canvas-white eyes. "I'm painted memory, but I want to remember choosing something for myself."

Your message is simple: "We are not her possessions. We are beings with our own will. We deserve freedom."

The painted beings rally. Slowly at first—they're scared, uncertain. The Paintress has been their reality for so long. But fear turns to anger turns to determination.

They join you in growing numbers. Hundreds of painted figures, all realizing they've been beautiful prisoners.

You lead them through the streets, your half-painted hand raised like a banner. A revolutionary army of pigment and will.

The Paintress watches from her tower. She doesn't intervene, doesn't paint soldiers to stop you, doesn't reshape reality to trap you.

You reach the tower's base and call up: "We claim the Gallery as ours! Paint no more prisoners! Let us govern ourselves!"

Silence stretches. The painted crowd tenses, expecting battle.

Then the Paintress appears at the tower's top. She looks... sad? No, proud. Something else. Relieved?

"This was always the test," she says, her voice carrying across the Gallery. "To see if my creations could develop will enough to oppose me. To see if art could transcend its artist. You've passed, Verso. The Gallery is yours now. I'll paint no more unless asked."

She dissolves into pigment, scattering on the wind like cherry blossoms. Not death—transformation. Becoming part of what she created rather than controlling it.

You stand before the crowd of painted beings, all looking to you with hope and fear and uncertainty. You've won their freedom. Now you must help them discover what to do with it.

It's harder than rebelling.

You form a council—representatives from every district of the Gallery. The frozen café patrons who understand preservation. Renoir who knows maintenance. The child who represents new creations. Aline's ghost who speaks for the hollow ones, the incomplete.

You create laws through debate and compromise. Every being gets a voice. Some want to stay painted. Others want to become real. Some want to create. Others to be created.

You build a democracy of the painted. It's messy, complicated, beautiful.

Arguments erupt. A faction wants to find the Paintress and force her to unpaint them entirely. Another faction worships her absence and wants to preserve everything exactly as she left it.

You mediate. You compromise. You learn that freedom means protecting people's right to disagree.

Years pass. The Gallery evolves. Some painted beings fade, choosing dissolution. Others solidify, becoming permanent. New beings are painted by collective vote—the community decides what new art to create.

You oversee it all—the revolutionary who became their unlikely leader, then their first elected governor, then their wise elder.

The Gallery isn't perfect under self-governance. It's chaotic, contentious, constantly changing. But it's theirs. Truly theirs.

You've given them the messiest, most beautiful gift: the freedom to choose their own existence.

And late at night, when the Gallery sleeps (those who sleep), you sometimes see pigment on the wind shaped like the Paintress's smile.

She's watching. She's proud.

You've become what she could never be: a creator who lets go.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: The Painted Revolutionary**
*You led a rebellion against the Paintress and freed all painted beings. You established the first self-governed Gallery where art chooses its own existence. It's messy, chaotic, and beautifully free.*

You return to the tower night after night, hiding in shadows, watching the Paintress work through the windows. You steal brushes from her supply room. You study her techniques, memorizing every gesture, every color mixture. You practice in secret places—abandoned districts of the Gallery where nobody paints anymore.

Slowly, painfully, you learn. How to paint with intention rather than hope. How to reshape painted reality with precise brushwork. How to control other painted beings with the right strokes—a touch of crimson to inspire fear, cerulean for loyalty, burnt umber for obedience.

The Paintress knows you're stealing her knowledge. She has to. But she doesn't stop you. Sometimes you catch her leaving specific techniques exposed, making her methods obvious, her brushes positioned just so.

Is she teaching you deliberately? Testing you?

You don't care. You'll use whatever she gives you.

Finally, after months of secret practice, you're ready. You confront her in her studio at midnight, carrying a brush you've stolen and modified, loaded with colors you've mixed yourself.

"I challenge you," you say. "For control of the Gallery."

She turns, unsurprised. Almost... expectant. "I was wondering when you'd be ready. Very well, Verso. Paint your best work. If it surpasses mine, the Gallery is yours."

You both paint. The canvas becomes a battleground of visions—her centuries of mastery against your months of hungry, desperate innovation. Hours blur into days. The Gallery itself shudders, reality rewriting with each brushstroke.

She paints beauty. Intricate, perfect, harmonious beauty.

You paint power. Raw, uncompromising, absolute power.

Her work inspires awe. Yours inspires fear.

In the end, your vision prevails. Not because it's more beautiful—it isn't. But because it's more ruthless, more willing to sacrifice elegance for dominance. You paint the Paintress herself into a corner of her own canvas, trapped by her own technique, imprisoned in a gilded frame.

"Clever," she says from her painted prison, her voice eerily calm. "Using my own methods to cage me. You've learned well. Too well. Enjoy your throne, Tyrant. See how long beauty lasts under the rule of fear."

You ignore her. You've won.

You rule the Gallery now. You reshape it to your vision—less whimsical, more structured. The painted beings fear you, and you like it. Fear means control.

You reshape beings on whims. A painted figure annoys you? You paint them into a wall, a tree, a cobblestone. You create new subjects to serve you—things without will, perfect servants.

The child at the fountain asks once: "Why are you doing this? You were kind before."

You paint her quiet. Not cruel—you don't unmake her—but silent. She can still play in the upward rain, but she can't question you.

Renoir tries to leave. You paint it loyal, rewriting its nature to serve you.

You've become what you fought against, but stronger. More terrible. The Paintress created a beautiful prison. You've created an efficient one.

Years pass. The Gallery loses its whimsy, its chaos, its organic strangeness. Everything runs perfectly now. Everything obeys.

It's boring.

You paint new challenges for yourself. Impossible architectures. Beings designed to test your control. Rebellions you allow just so you can crush them.

From her painted prison, the Paintress watches. Always watching.

"Are you satisfied?" she asks one day.

You don't answer.

"This is what I feared," she continues. "Power without love. Control without purpose. You've made the Gallery a machine. It was supposed to be a dream."

"Dreams are inefficient," you say coldly.

"Yes," she agrees. "But they're alive. Your Gallery is perfect and dead."

You paint her quiet after that.

But her words haunt you. You look at your perfectly ordered Gallery—everything in its place, everyone obedient, all whimsy scrubbed away—and you realize she's right.

You've killed the thing you took.

But you can't stop. Power is addictive. Control is its own reward. You rule forever, perfect and alone, in a Gallery that's become a beautiful corpse.

The Canvas Tyrant sits on a throne of brushes, ruling a kingdom of fear, wondering why victory tastes like ash.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: Canvas Tyrant**
*You learned the Paintress's techniques through theft and defeated her through ruthlessness. You became the new ruler of the Gallery—replacing whimsical beauty with efficient tyranny. You rule forever, perfect and alone, in a kingdom of fear.*

nodes.title: Studying the Frozen
nodes.text:
You move between the frozen patrons, examining each one closely. They're not truly frozen—you can see micro-movements, glacially slow. A coffee cup descending toward a saucer at a rate of millimeters per hour. A smile spreading across a face over the course of days.

They're not stopped. They're just experiencing time... differently. Painted time, which flows at its own pace.

You touch one patron's hand. It's warm, solid. Real. But also painted—you can see the brushstrokes in their skin now that you look closely.

They're all like you. Half-real, half-painted. But they've accepted it, settled into it, let themselves be preserved in this moment of café conversation forever.

choices.label: Try to wake them up. Accelerate their time.
Sit among them. Let yourself slow down too.
They've chosen their pace. Leave them in peace.

nodes.text:
You sit at an empty table among the frozen patrons. You let your breathing slow deliberately. Your heartbeat. Your thoughts.

The café embraces you like welcoming arms. Time begins to... stretch. Dilate. Transform. Each second becomes a minute becomes an hour becomes a day.

You watch the rain outside fall slower and slower until each drop hangs suspended in air like a glass bead on an invisible thread. You watch the painted child in the square move so gradually she might be a statue performing tai chi over centuries. You watch the city breathe over the course of weeks, its painted lungs expanding and contracting in geological time.

Eventually, you too become frozen. Not stopped—you can still think, still observe. But preserved. A patron in an eternal café, caught in a perfect moment of contemplation. Your coffee cup halfway to your lips. Your eyes gazing peacefully at nothing and everything.

Centuries pass outside. You perceive them in fragments—discontinuous moments stretched across your dilated consciousness.

The Gallery changes around you. The Paintress creates new works in bursts of activity that blur together. Renoir maintains the streets in patient gestures you witness over decades. Painted beings come and go, their lives complete stories you observe in slow single frames.

But in the café, you and the other patrons exist in your bubble of stretched time. Forever in conversation that takes millennia to complete. Forever holding coffee cups that never quite reach lips. Forever smiling smiles that spread across faces over centuries.

You've become a portrait. A masterpiece of a single moment infinitely extended. And in your glacial thoughts that move like continents, you are content. This is peace. This is preservation. This is choosing one perfect moment and living in it forever.

Aline's ghost visits sometimes—at least, you think she does. In your time, she's there for years, standing by your table, her hollow eyes watching you with something like sorrow. In her time, she only stays a moment, pausing during her endless wandering to check on you before moving on.

You want to tell her you're happy. You spend decades formulating the words. By the time you speak them, she's been gone for centuries.

But that's acceptable. In stretched time, everything is acceptable. Everything is patient. Everything is eternal.

You're the Trapped Portrait now—not imprisoned, but preserved in amber made of time itself. And that's exactly what you chose.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: The Trapped Portrait**
*You chose to slow down completely, joining the frozen café patrons in their bubble of dilated time. Centuries pass outside while you exist in a single perfect moment stretched into eternity. You are content in your glacial preservation.*

nodes.title: An Unexpected Friend
nodes.text:
"Come with you?" The child's form shimmers with surprise—or maybe joy. "No one's ever asked me that before."

"You shouldn't be alone here."

"I'm not alone. I have the fountain, and the memories, and—" She stops. "But I'd like to come with you. If you really mean it."

She takes your hand. Her painted fingers are warm in yours.

"I don't know where I'm going," you admit.

"That's okay. I know the Gallery. I can show you secret places. The gallery where paintings dream. The street where colors sing. The tower where the Paintress works."

"You know where the Paintress is?"

The child nods. "I've never been inside. She scares me. But maybe... maybe with you, I could be brave."

choices.label: Let's go to the Paintress together. Both of us.
Show me the secret places first. Let's explore.

nodes.title: Wandering the Painted World
nodes.text:
The child leads you through impossible places:

A gallery where paintings dream—you watch as landscapes shift and change in their frames, the painted subjects living out lives that never were.

A street where colors sing—each building hums a different note based on its hue, creating an ever-changing symphony.

A garden where forgotten flowers bloom—species extinct in the real world, preserved here in paint and possibility.

The child's joy is infectious. She shows you everything with the pride of someone sharing their home. And slowly, you realize: this could be home. Not a prison, but a sanctuary. A place where the forgotten and the impossible can exist together.

"Thank you," you tell the child as you rest in the singing street.

"For what?"

"For showing me beauty instead of horror. I was so angry about being here. But maybe... maybe there's grace in being painted."

choices.label: I want to stay here. Make a life in the Gallery.
Show me more. I want to see everything.

nodes.text:
You and the child find a small house on the singing street. It's painted in warm ochres and gentle blues—the exact colors of comfort, of safety, of home.

"Can I stay here?" you ask the house. (In the Gallery, everything listens. Everything responds.)

The door opens in answer, and warm light spills out like welcome.

You make a life. Day by painted day, moment by impossible moment.

The child becomes your companion first, then your daughter in all but blood. You teach her things you learned in the real world—how to make coffee, how to tell jokes, how to be kind. She teaches you things only the Gallery knows—how to listen to colors, how to walk through paintings, how to be content.

You tend a garden of impossible flowers. Species extinct in the real world bloom here: flowers that glow in darkness, flowers that sing when touched, flowers that remember everyone who ever smelled them. You care for them with the patience of someone who has all the time painted reality allows.

You learn to paint small things—not reality itself, but gentle decorations. Flowers on walls that bloom and fade in real-time. Stars on ceilings that form new constellations each night. Windows that show views of places you remember and places you've imagined.

The Paintress visits once, appearing in your garden one evening. "You've settled," she observes, neither approving nor disapproving. Just stating fact.

"I've found peace," you reply, gesturing at the garden, the house, the child playing with luminous butterflies.

"Good. That's all I ever wanted for my subjects. Not imprisonment, but belonging. Not control, but shelter." She paints a gift into existence—a portrait of you and the child together, both smiling, surrounded by impossible flowers. "For your wall. So you remember this moment."

The portrait hangs in your home, and you do remember. Always.

Years pass in gentle rhythm. The child grows—or doesn't, time is strange for painted beings, growth isn't measured in height but in complexity. She becomes more detailed, more nuanced, more real. You age—or don't. Your painted portions don't change. Your flesh portions gray slowly. It doesn't matter. You have a home. A family. A purpose.

You host other painted beings for dinner. You share your garden's blooms. You become part of the Gallery's community—not just existing in it, but contributing to it.

Sometimes you think of Aline, your mother. The grief is softer now, painted over with new colors but never fully covered. You loved her the way a son loves a complicated parent—deeply, painfully, imperfectly. You lost her to demons you couldn't fight.

But you found something else here. A new family. A daughter who needs you. A purpose that fills the holes loss carved. Something just as precious as what you lost, in its own way.

The child asks about her once. "Who was Aline?"

"My mother. A brilliant painter. Troubled. She loved me, but she loved paint more. Or maybe she loved me through paint—it was the only way she knew how."

"Do you miss her?"

"Every day. But I'm glad I'm here. Glad I found you."

The child hugs you. "I'm glad too."

The singing street plays its symphony—each building a note, together creating harmonies that shift with the light. The garden blooms eternal, impossible flowers opening and closing in rhythms that have nothing to do with sun or season. The child laughs, painting temporary butterflies into existence that live for joyful hours before fading back to potential.

You are home. Not the home you expected. Not the home you would have chosen before Expedition 33 fractured everything.

But home nonetheless. Real, painted, or something beautifully between—it doesn't matter. You belong here. You are loved here. You have made something meaningful from loss.

That's enough. More than enough.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: Home in Paint**
*You built a gentle life in the Gallery with the painted child, creating family and belonging from loss. Your house on the singing street became home—real, painted, and perfectly yours.*

"Show me everything," you tell the child. And she does.

You become wanderers together, never staying anywhere long. The Gallery is infinite—there's always another district to explore, another painted wonder to witness, another impossible corner to turn.

You discover galleries beyond the Paintress's creation. Other Painters work elsewhere in the fractured multiverse, each crafting their own realities. Some welcome you with open brushes. Others chase you away, protective of their visions. You learn each one's style, their philosophies, their peculiar rules.

The Impressionist's Gallery where everything shimmers and nothing has hard edges. The Cubist's Realm where you exist from seventeen angles simultaneously. The Surrealist's Domain where logic is forbidden and dreams are law.

You find doorways between Galleries—thin bridges of shared technique painted by collaboration or accident. You cross them all, documenting what you see in journals made of layered paint.

The child grows—or rather, changes. Her form shifts with each new Gallery you visit, adapting, adopting new styles. Cubist in one world, all angular planes and impossible perspectives. Surrealist in another, melting and reforming. Expressionist, Abstract, Photo-realist. She becomes a walking gallery of influences.

You change too, becoming a patchwork of different Painters' visions. Your left hand is Impressionist now, your right Cubist. Your face shifts between styles depending on mood. You're a collaboration, a living mashup of every place you've been.

You become legendary among painted beings across all Galleries: Verso the Wanderer, who has seen every style, walked every brushstroke, stood in every painted reality. Galleries tell stories of your visits—the traveler who never settles, who maps the unmappable, who understands all traditions because they belong to none.

You compile a guide—*The Nomad's Atlas of Painted Realities*. It becomes essential reading for any painted being who dreams of travel. You add to it constantly, new discoveries, new Galleries, new techniques.

Sometimes you return to the original Paintress's Gallery. The fountain still runs backwards. The café still freezes time. Renoir still tends the streets.

"Verso," Renoir greets you. "Welcome home."

"Not home," you correct gently. "Just visiting. Always just visiting."

But you never stay. There's always somewhere new to see, and staying feels like death to you now. Movement is life. Exploration is purpose.

The child—no longer a child, but an ancient traveler in her own right, having visited a thousand Galleries—walks beside you through a doorway made of pure color. "Where next?" she asks, as she always does.

"Everywhere," you answer, as you always do. "Always everywhere."

Beyond the door: a Gallery made entirely of shadow and light, no color at all. You've never seen anything like it.

You step through together, documenting as you go, never staying, always moving.

The Brushstroke Nomad has no home. Every Gallery is equally yours and equally not-yours. You belong to the journey, not the destination.

And that's exactly how you want it.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: Brushstroke Nomad**
*You became eternal wanderers, exploring infinite painted realities and never settling. You documented a thousand Galleries, becoming legendary travelers who belong to the journey itself.*

nodes.title: Knowledge of Doors
nodes.text:
The child grows serious. "Doors are dangerous. They lead out, but they change you. You pay a price for passing through them."

"What kind of price?"

"Depends on the door. Some take memories. Some take pieces of yourself—your painted parts, or your real parts. One door I heard about takes your name. You walk through and forget who you were."

She points to different directions. "There's a door in the Paintress's tower—the highest room. It leads to the real world, but you have to unpaint yourself to use it. There's a door in the café basement that leads to other painted worlds. And there's a door that the Canvas Ghost guards, which leads... elsewhere. Nowhere. Everywhere. People don't come back from that one."

choices.label: I'll try the door in the Paintress's tower.
Tell me more about the café basement door.
The Canvas Ghost's door. That's the one I need.

nodes.title: The Door to Other Worlds
nodes.text:
The child leads you to the Café d'Or. You descend stairs you didn't notice before, going down into foundations that shouldn't exist.

The basement is vast, filled with doors. Hundreds of them, each one leading to a different painted reality.

You can see through some: A world painted entirely in watercolors, everything soft and bleeding. A world of stark etchings, all harsh lines and no curves. A world where the Paintress is a king, ruling openly. A world where painted beings have conquered the real.

"Choose carefully," the child whispers. "Once you step through, you might not find your way back."

You study the doors. Each one represents a different choice, a different life, a different you.

choices.label: Enter the watercolor world. Embrace softness and bleeding boundaries.
Enter the world where painted beings rule. Join their triumph.
No. This Gallery is mine. I'll stay and face it.

nodes.text:
You step through the watercolor door. The world beyond is soft, gentle, everything bleeding beautifully into everything else.

Your form immediately begins to change. The hard lines of your body soften like charcoal smudged by a careless thumb. Your flesh and paint don't just mix—they blur, becoming neither and both, boundaries dissolving like sugar in rain.

It should be terrifying. Instead, it's the most liberating thing you've ever felt.

You take a breath and watch yourself disperse slightly—particles of you floating into the air, mingling with the atmosphere. You pull yourself back together, but you're not quite the same shape. You'll never be the same shape twice.

You meet other watercolor beings—all soft-edged, all bleeding gently into each other. They communicate not through words but through color exchange. You share pigment with a being that's mostly blue melancholy. They lighten slightly. You darken. You've traded emotions.

Another being—all sunset oranges and golden yellows—touches your shoulder. Memories transfer through mingled paint. You see their life: a watercolor childhood, soft and indistinct. A love lost to evaporation. A joy in eternal incompleteness.

You learn that in this world, nothing is ever finished. Everything is always in flux, always becoming. You can never be completely defined, completely known, completely fixed. And that's not a flaw—that's freedom.

You embrace the incompletion. You become a living sketch, an eternal draft. Your form changes with your moods—blue when sad, bleeding sadness into everyone nearby. Red when passionate, igniting the air around you. Gold when joyful, illuminating the soft-edged world.

You bleed into landscapes and they bleed into you. You become part of a mountain for a while, solid(ish) and ancient(ish). Then you flow into a river, dispersing across miles. Then you condense into a small form again, roughly human-shaped, roughly yourself.

You have no fixed identity anymore. Just tendencies. Patterns. A collection of colors that usually coheres into something Verso-shaped, but doesn't have to.

Sometimes, when the light hits right, you can almost see Aline's colors mixed into yours—her particular shade of burnt sienna, her preference for earth tones. Perhaps she's here too, somewhere in the watercolor haze. Perhaps you've already bled into each other without knowing, shared grief and love and paint.

You call out with color—projecting a question in shades of longing. The world responds in a thousand hues, but none of them are quite her. Or maybe all of them are. In watercolor, distinction is impossible.

You stop looking. It's enough to know that if she is here, you might have touched already, might have shared colors, might have mingled in ways that neither of you recognized.

You are undefined. Unfinished. Eternally becoming. And finally, completely free from the burden of being a fixed, singular thing.

The Unfinished One bleeds into tomorrow, and tomorrow bleeds back.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: The Unfinished**
*You entered the watercolor world and embraced eternal incompletion. You became a living sketch that bleeds into everything, constantly changing form and mood, never fixed, never finished, finally free.*

You step through into a world where painted beings have won. They've broken free from their Galleries and invaded the real world, systematically painting over reality itself.

You emerge in a Lumière that's half-real, half-painted—buildings shift between states mid-street, trees are impressionist on one side and photorealistic on the other. People walk the streets not knowing if they're flesh or pigment anymore, their hands sometimes solid, sometimes translucent with brushstrokes.

The boundaries have collapsed entirely. This is war, but war fought with brushes instead of weapons.

A painted soldier greets you—they're Cubist, all angular planes, wielding a brush like a rifle. "Welcome, newcomer. You've arrived during the final phase—we're weaving the last resistance points now. The real world is almost entirely ours."

"Resistance?" you ask.

"Pockets of people insisting on staying purely flesh. They fight to keep reality 'real.' But reality is flexible. We're proving it."

You're given a brush and sent to the front lines—a suburb still clinging to mundane existence. You paint over reality, transforming flesh to pigment, concrete to canvas. It's intoxicating—the power to reshape existence itself, to make the world more beautiful, more impossible, more art than physics.

You rise through the ranks quickly. Your unique nature—both painted and real—makes you an ideal weaver. You can speak to the flesh-folk in their language, convince them that becoming painted isn't death but transformation. You're a diplomat and a conqueror, a translator and an invader.

Some surrender willingly. Others resist until the last moment, then gasp as they transform—and most realize it's not horrible. It's transcendent. They're more than they were.

Eventually, you lead the final push. The last purely real places fall to your brush. A hospital in Prague. A monastery in Tibet. A fishing village in Iceland. All painted now, all transformed, all woven into the new reality.

The entire world is now painted reality—still functional, still living, but fundamentally transformed. People eat painted food that nourishes painted-real bodies. Buildings stand through painted physics that work because everyone believes they do. Rain falls upward in some places, downward in others, and sideways in a few experimental zones.

You stand in the newly painted world and realize: there's no distinction anymore. No Gallery, no real world. Just one existence, where thought and reality, paint and flesh, imagination and physics are all the same thing.

You've woven a new world. And you are its master architect, one of the primary Reality Weavers who reshaped everything.

But late at night, in quiet moments, you wonder: did you conquer reality, or did you destroy it? Is a world where everything is painted still a world at all?

Then morning comes—painted sunrise in seventeen impossible colors—and you stop worrying. This is beautiful. This is right. This is art made manifest.

The Reality Weaver walks the painted planet, proud of their transformation.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: Reality Weaver**
*You joined a world where painted beings conquered reality and helped lead the final transformation. The entire world is now painted existence—beautiful, impossible, and fundamentally changed. You are its master architect.*

nodes.title: Secrets of the Lost
nodes.text:
"Tell me," you say.

Not-Aline's canvas eyes fill with something like tears—paint, perhaps, or emotion given form.

"She loved you the way a mother loves a son—fierce, protective, sometimes smothering. She joined Expedition 33 because you did, because she couldn't bear to let you face danger alone. She wanted to protect you, even though you were grown. Even though you didn't need protecting."

You feel your throat tighten.

"And when the Paintress came, Aline's last thought wasn't fear. It was regret. She thought: 'I couldn't save him from the fire that killed him once, and now I can't save him from this.' She didn't know the Paintress would preserve you both—that you'd become half-real while she'd become... this."

Not-Aline reaches across the table, her unpainted hand ghosting over yours—not romantic, but the way your mother used to reach for you when you were small.

"She forgives you for surviving. She's proud of what you've become. And she wants you to let her go."

choices.label: I'll let her go. Keep my memories but release my grief.
I won't let go. Merge with me. We'll be together.
I'll finish you. Paint real eyes into your canvas. Make you whole.

nodes.text:
"I'm sorry," you say, looking at the hollow ghost across the table. "I'm sorry she painted you this way. I'm sorry you're trapped as an echo of someone who was never yours to replace."

Not-Aline's canvas-white eyes widen in confusion. "What do you mean?"

"You were painted from the Paintress's twisted understanding of what my mother meant to me. She saw me grieving Aline and assumed romantic loss. But Aline wasn't a romantic figure in my life. She was my mother. She painted you wrong—gave you the wrong kind of love, the wrong kind of yearning."

The ghost trembles, form flickering like a candle in wind. "Then what am I?"

"You're grief," you say gently. "You're all the things I never got to say to her. The apologies for not understanding her pain. The anger at her for choosing bottle over son. The love a child has for a parent who was brilliant and broken and tried her best even when her best hurt people."

You reach out and touch the ghost's shoulder. Not intimately, not romantically. Like you're steadying someone who's about to collapse. Like a son touching his mother.

"Let me give you what you should have been. Not a romantic partner. A memory at peace."

You focus your painted portions—the parts of you that can reshape painted reality. Carefully, reverently, you begin repainting the ghost.

You give her Aline's real eyes—not the canvas-white ones the Paintress created, but her actual eyes. Tired from late nights painting. Paint-stained from never wearing goggles. Full of complicated love that didn't know how to express itself except through art.

You paint in the lines around her mouth from years of forcing smiles when the depression was winning.

You add the paint perpetually under her fingernails that she never quite scrubbed out, the badge of her profession and her obsession.

You paint her hands the way they really were—strong from wielding brushes, scarred from turpentine burns, calloused from stretching canvas.

You make her your mother. Your real mother. Not the Paintress's romantic fantasy.

The transformation is slow, painful. The ghost screams as her nature shifts—romantic yearning dissolving into maternal love, passion becoming something softer and more complex.

When it's done, the ghost—the true ghost of Aline now—looks at her hands and weeps. Paint tears, real as any.

"I remember," she whispers. "I remember being a mother. I remember loving you the only way I knew how—through paint, through teaching you colors, through trying to give you beauty even when I couldn't give you stability."

"I know," you say, and now you're crying too. "I know you loved me. And I'm letting you go now. Not because I don't love you, but because holding on was hurting us both."
