She reaches out, touches your face one last time. Her hand is warm, painted but real. "You were the best thing I ever made," she says. "Better than any painting. I'm sorry I didn't tell you that more."

"You told me through art," you reply. "I just had to learn the language."

She fades slowly, peacefully, no longer bound by the Paintress's misunderstanding or your desperate need to keep her close. As she disappears, you feel lighter. Not because you've forgotten—but because you've finally said goodbye properly.

You carry her memory now. Not as a ghost haunting the Gallery, but as a son who's made peace with an imperfect parent. You remember her brilliance and her demons. Her talent and her struggles. Her love expressed in brushstrokes when words failed.

And that's enough. That's the right way to remember her.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: Aline's Echo**
*You corrected the Paintress's mistake by repainting your mother's ghost from romantic figure to actual parent. You said goodbye properly—as a son to a flawed, brilliant, loving mother—and found peace in letting her go.*

nodes.title: The Ghost's Desire
nodes.text:
"What do you want?" you ask Not-Aline.

She's quiet for a long moment. Then: "I want to be finished. The Paintress started painting me but never completed the work. I'm a sketch, Verso. An outline. I have Aline's shape but none of her depth."

"So you want me to..."

"I want you to either complete me or erase me. I can't stay like this—hollow, incomplete, neither real nor fully painted. It's agony."

She stands, and you see how thin she is—literally two-dimensional in places, missing entire layers of paint and reality.

"The Paintress gave you the ability to change your own paint. That means you could change mine too. You could finish what she started. Or you could paint me out entirely, let me rest."

The choice hangs heavy in the frozen air.

choices.label: I'll complete you. Make you real.
I'll let you rest. Paint you out gently.
I can't make this choice. You have to stay as you are.

nodes.title: Refusing the Path
nodes.text:
"No," you say, standing abruptly. "I won't participate in this. Not your memories, not your requests, not any of it. The Paintress set all this up—every interaction, every choice. I won't play her game."

Not-Aline looks sad but not surprised. "Then what will you do?"

"Find my own way. One she hasn't painted yet."

You leave the café, stepping back into the rain. Your hand—flesh and paint—clenches into a fist. You won't accept transformation or escape or any of the Paintress's prescribed paths.

You'll create a third option. A fourth. A hundredth.

You'll break every rule she's painted into this place until you find a door she never imagined.

The Canvas Ghost appears before you, materializing from rain and shadow. "Rebellion," it says. "How interesting. Follow me. I have something to show you."

choices.label: Follow the Canvas Ghost.
No. I follow no one. Not even you.

nodes.title: Learning the Threshold
nodes.text:
Renoir becomes your teacher. You spend time—impossible to measure here—learning to exist between states.

You practice bleeding paint into reality. Pulling reality into paint. Standing with one foot in each world and refusing to choose.

You learn to see both truths simultaneously: the real Lumière and the painted Gallery, occupying the same space. You learn to interact with both, affecting neither too heavily.

"A mediator doesn't force change," Renoir teaches. "They facilitate conversation. You help painted beings understand reality. You help real beings accept the painted. You are translation itself."

One day, Renoir brings you before the Canvas Ghost. "Your student is ready," it says.

The Ghost circles you, examining. "Almost," it finally says. "One more lesson. The hardest one."

choices.label: Teach me. I'm ready.
Let me test my skills first. I want to mediate something real.

nodes.title: Self-Taught Balance
nodes.text:
"Thank you, Renoir," you say. "But I need to find my own balance. Not one taught by curators or ghosts, but one I discover myself."

Renoir bows slightly. "The harder path. But perhaps the truer one. Go, then. Learn by doing. Fail. Succeed. Find your equilibrium."

You walk the Gallery alone, experimenting. You try to paint with your fingers—sometimes it works, creating small changes. Sometimes it fails, leaving you exhausted.

You try to write truth into the painted world—naming things and having them become more real. Sometimes it works. Sometimes the Gallery rejects your words.

Slowly, through trial and error, you develop your own style. Not quite Painter. Not quite Writer. Something uniquely yours.

You become a mediator through practice rather than training. Rough-edged, imperfect, but authentic.

choices.label: Keep developing your unique style.
Find someone to practice with. Balance needs two sides.

nodes.text:
Through years of self-directed practice, you perfect your own unique style of existing between states. You don't call yourself a Mediator—that's Renoir's word. You are a Frame Walker.

You've learned to see reality as a series of frames, like a painting's border defines what's inside and outside the composition. You walk those frames, existing in the boundary itself—neither within nor without, but permanently on the edge.

You can frame anything: A moment in time, freezing it into a perfect tableau like the café patrons exist in their eternal conversation. A person, defining precisely what they are and aren't, giving them clear boundaries in the Gallery's chaos. An entire district, setting its rules and limits with careful framing.

Painted beings come to you when they want to interact with the real world—you frame them in ways that make them visible, tangible to flesh folk. Real people—the rare few who stumble into the Gallery by accident—come to you when they need a guide back, and you frame doorways home for them.

You stand at every threshold, opening and closing frames as needed. You are the border guard, the doorkeeper, the edge-walker.

The Paintress calls you her finest work: "A piece of art that defines other art. Meta-creation. You frame my work, making it comprehensible."

The Canvas Ghost calls you its equal: "Another being who exists in the between. Perhaps you understand better than I do now."

Renoir calls you graduate: "You've surpassed anything I could have taught. You created your own tradition."

But you call yourself simply Verso: The one who turns the page. The one who stands at the frame's edge. The one who decides what's inside and what's outside, and understands that the border itself is where all interesting things happen—where meaning is made, where definitions shift, where transformation occurs.

You are the Master of Frames, and every boundary in the Gallery answers to you.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: Master of Frames**
*You developed your own self-taught style, becoming a Frame Walker who controls all boundaries. You frame moments, people, and entire districts—making you the Gallery's master of edges and thresholds.*

nodes.title: Seeking Partnership
nodes.text:
You realize that true balance requires partnership. The Canvas Ghost exists between states—perhaps it would understand your journey better than anyone.

You seek it out, calling into the white spaces between buildings: "Canvas Ghost. I wish to speak with you. Not as supplicant, but as equal. Or as potential equal."

The world folds. You're suddenly in the white space, facing the Ghost.

"Potential equal," it muses. "Interesting phrasing. What do you propose, Verso?"

"Teach me to be like you. Or better—teach me to complement you. Two beings of the threshold, working together. One who tends toward the painted, one who tends toward the real. Both meeting in the middle."

choices.label: Be my partner. Together we could perfect the threshold.
Or let me replace you. Become the new Canvas Ghost.

nodes.text:
The Canvas Ghost considers your proposal. Silence stretches in the white space—or perhaps centuries pass, time is meaningless here.

Finally: "Partnership. No one has ever offered before. They beg for passage or challenge for power. But partnership..." Its spiral eyes focus intently. "Yes. Let us be partners in threshold. I will teach you my nature, and you will teach me yours."

You take its hand—if hand is the right word. Knowledge floods both ways through the contact. You learn to exist as pure negative space, to be the absence that defines presence, to understand being through not-being. It learns to experience flesh and paint simultaneously, to be positively hybrid rather than negatively empty, to understand presence through dual-existence.

Together, you become perfect mediators. The Ghost handles philosophical transitions—concepts becoming reality, reality becoming concept, the abstract made concrete. You handle physical transitions—painted becoming real, real becoming painted, the concrete made abstract.

You split the Gallery's maintenance perfectly. The Ghost tends to abstract spaces, impossible geometries, conceptual districts where thought is made manifest. You tend to concrete places—the cafe, the fountain, the streets where paint and reality actually touch.

Visitors to the Gallery now encounter two threshold guardians instead of one: The Canvas Ghost, ancient and empty and wise in the ways of absence. And Verso, young and full and wise in the ways of dual presence. Together you offer every kind of passage, every variety of transformation.

Sometimes you merge into one being, experiencing perfect threshold unity—neither you nor Ghost but something beautifully combined. Sometimes you separate completely, each tending your own domain independently. The partnership is fluid, ever-changing, perfectly balanced.

You have found your equal. And in finding them, you have become fully yourself—not despite partnership but because of it.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: Ghost's Equal**
*You became partner and equal to the Canvas Ghost. Together you maintain perfect balance between all states, offering every kind of transformation to those who seek passage.*

nodes.title: The Painter's Truth
nodes.text:
Renoir's form ripples with something like memory. "The Paintress. She was human once, did you know? A painter in the real world. But not content with painting representations, she wanted to paint reality itself."

"She found a way?"

"She became a way. Transformed herself into pure artistic intent. She created this Gallery as her canvas, painting endless variations of reality. Every Expedition she intercepts, every person she paints into existence—they're all part of her grand work."

"But why trap people here?"

"She doesn't see it as trapping. To her, she's preserving them. Making them eternal. In her view, flesh decays but paint endures. She's saving everyone she touches."

Renoir's voice drops lower. "The tragedy is, she's not entirely wrong. You are more permanent now than you ever were in flesh. But permanence and imprisonment can look very similar from certain angles."

choices.label: Maybe she has a point. Maybe permanence is worth the cost.
Permanence without choice is just a beautiful prison.
Perhaps there's a middle way between her vision and escape.

nodes.title: Seeking Shelter
nodes.text:
"Help me hide," you say. "Just for a while. Until I understand what I'm dealing with."

Renoir nods. "I can paint you into the backgrounds. Make you part of the scenery—visible but not noticed. The Paintress sees everything, but she doesn't process everything. Too many details in her masterpiece."

"Will it hurt?"

"It will feel like... fading. But temporary. You can emerge whenever you choose."

Renoir touches your shoulder. Your painted portions begin to shift, blending with the street behind you. You become part of a wall, part of a shadow, part of the rain-slicked cobblestones.

You can still see, still think, but you're camouflaged perfectly. The Paintress's attention sweeps past you multiple times, never quite focusing.

From this hidden vantage, you watch the Gallery. You see how it operates. How the Paintress creates. How Renoir maintains. How the Canvas Ghost observes. You learn without being taught.

choices.label: Emerge from hiding with new understanding.
Stay hidden. Become permanent background.

nodes.text:
You decide not to emerge. The background is safe. Quiet. Peaceful. No one expects anything from a wall or a shadow or a cobblestone. You can simply be, without the burden of being someone.

Days pass. Weeks. Years. Your consciousness diffuses across the scenery like watercolor bleeding through paper. You become part of many places at once—a brick in the café wall experiencing conversations, a ripple in the fountain touching upward-flowing water, a shadow in the Paintress's tower watching her create.

You watch everything without participating, a perfect observer without agenda. The painted child grows older (or doesn't—time is strange for backgrounds). Renoir continues its eternal maintenance, occasionally brushing past surfaces that contain pieces of you. The Paintress paints new subjects who arrive and struggle and eventually settle or escape or transform. You witness all their stories from within the walls.

You see Aline's ghost fading gradually, her already-thin form becoming transparent over what might be months or might be decades. One day she's simply gone, dissolved back into base pigment. You feel a distant sadness, but you're too dispersed to hold strong emotion. It passes through you like wind through leaves.

You've become the Gallery itself—not a curator like Renoir, not a creator like the Paintress, but the substrate on which everything else exists. You are the canvas beneath all other paint, the walls that hold the art, the ground beneath their feet.

Sometimes you wonder if you should emerge, reconstitute, reclaim your form, become Verso again. But the wondering is lazy, diffuse. It never coheres into action. Why be a person when you can be a place?

You are content as background. There's a profound peace in being scenery—existing without responsibility, present without pressure, eternal without effort.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: Faded to Background**
*You chose to remain hidden forever, diffusing into the Gallery's background. You became the quiet substrate—the walls, shadows, and surfaces on which all other existences play out their stories.*

nodes.title: Knowledge From Shadows
nodes.text:
You emerge from the backgrounds, reconstituting your form. Renoir nods approvingly.

"You've learned much," it observes.

"I've seen how it all works. The Paintress creates from inspiration and compulsion. You maintain from duty and care. The Canvas Ghost exists from necessity and curiosity. And me..."

"You exist from transformation," Renoir finishes. "You're the only one who's still changing, still choosing. That makes you powerful, Verso. More powerful than any of us, perhaps."

"What should I do with that power?"

"That's not for me to say. But you have options no one else has. You can paint and be painted. You can stay and leave. You can accept and rebel. You exist at every threshold simultaneously."

The rain has stopped. The city gleams, fresh and new.

choices.label: Use this power to create. Add to the Gallery.
Use this power to liberate. Free the painted beings.
Use this power to balance. Mediate between all forces.

nodes.text:
You realize the Gallery doesn't have to stay as the Paintress designed it. You can add to it. Improve it. Redesign its fundamental structure using your unique understanding of both painted and real.

You begin small—adding details to existing buildings, creating new painted beings who are more complete than the Paintress's sketches. You give the painted child proper parents who love her. You paint Aline's ghost into full reality, completing what the Paintress left unfinished, giving her peace.

The Paintress watches your work with interest. She doesn't stop you. Perhaps she approves? Or perhaps she's curious to see what her creation will create—the artwork that makes new art.

You grow bolder. You add entire new districts to the Gallery: A district where music is visible, flowing through the streets like colorful rivers you can swim through. A district where memories are traded as currency, creating economies of experience. A district where time flows in all directions at once, letting people experience their lives non-linearly.

Other painted beings bring you their problems, and you architect solutions. Someone feels incomplete? You paint in their missing pieces with care and precision. Someone wants to change form entirely? You redesign them, reshape them into who they want to be. Someone wants to leave but fears the real world? You paint them transition spaces where they can practice being flesh before committing.

You've become the Gallery's architect, its urban planner, its designer of dreams and realities. Where the Paintress created the foundation, you add the flourishes. Where she painted in broad strokes, you add intricate details that make the difference between existing and truly living.

The Gallery grows under your attention, becoming richer, more complex, more wondrous with each passing year. You are creation incarnate, forever improving the painted world, forever expanding the possible.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: The Gallery Architect**
*You became the Gallery's architect, redesigning and vastly expanding it. You added new districts, completed unfinished beings, and created solutions for every problem—making the painted world richer and more livable.*

nodes.title: Finishing the Portrait
nodes.text:
"I'll complete you," you say. "Give you what the Paintress didn't."

Not-Aline's form trembles—hope and fear mingling. "Are you sure? Once I'm complete, I'll be truly separate from her. A different person with Aline's face."

"That's who you should be."

You focus on your painted portions, learning to control them. Slowly, painfully, you begin painting into Not-Aline. You give her real eyes—not canvas-white, but the warm brown you remember. You paint depth into her form, layer after layer, building three-dimensionality.

You paint memories into her—not the ones the Paintress installed, but new ones. A childhood she never had. Dreams she could pursue. Desires that are hers alone.

It takes hours. Days. You paint and paint, exhausting yourself, but you don't stop.

Finally, she's complete. She blinks real eyes at you. "Verso? I... I can feel. Truly feel. I'm not hollow anymore."

She's not Aline. She's someone new. Someone who carries Aline's shape but has her own soul.

choices.label: Help her find her own path. Give her the freedom to become herself.
Set her free. She deserves her own life.

nodes.text:
The completed being—she chooses the name Celine, deliberately marking that she is not Aline—stands before you, finally whole. Real eyes blink. Real hands flex.

"Thank you," she says, and her voice is her own now, not an echo of anyone else's. "For seeing that I wasn't meant to be her. For giving me the chance to be someone new instead of someone's hollow replacement."

You realize what you've actually done. You haven't recreated your mother or kept her close in ghostly form. You've helped a confused, incomplete being find her own identity—free from the Paintress's fundamental misunderstanding of grief and love.

"What will you do now?" you ask.

Celine looks around the Gallery with wonder, seeing it fresh. "I think... I'll explore. Discover. Create my own story. I have her face, yes, but I'm not bound by her history. I can make my own choices, love my own loves, paint my own paintings."

She places a hand on your shoulder—not romantic, not maternal, but simply grateful. The gesture of someone who's been given the gift of autonomous existence.

"You gave me life, Verso. Real, independent life. Not as a replacement for your mother, not as your companion, but as my own complete person. I won't forget that. But I also won't stay close just because we share a face. I need to be me, whoever that turns out to be."

She leaves the café, walking out into the Gallery to discover who she wants to become.

You watch her go, feeling a strange mix of grief and peace and rightness. You've finally let go of your mother—not by merging with her ghost or replacing her or keeping her close, but by helping what remained of her become something entirely new and separate. That's the healthiest goodbye.

You exist in a strange state: split between painted and real, carrying memories of a mother you've now truly said goodbye to, having created new life from old grief.

You have found closure. Not through possession or romance or replacement, but through the act of letting go completely.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: Dual Existence**
*You completed your mother's ghost into Celine, an independent being free to forge her own identity. You found closure not through keeping her close, but through letting her become someone entirely new.*

nodes.title: A Gentle Ending
nodes.text:
"I'll let you rest," you say softly. "You deserve peace, not this hollow half-existence."

Not-Aline's relief is visible. "Thank you. I'm so tired, Verso. Tired of being almost-her. Almost-real. Almost-anything."

You learn to paint in reverse—removing brushstrokes instead of adding them. It's delicate work. You erase her gently, carefully, letting each layer fade with kindness.

As she disappears, she speaks: "Tell the real Aline, if you ever find her in some afterlife, that the ghost she left behind was grateful. For existence. For you. For this ending."

"I will."

The last brushstroke fades. She's gone. The chair across from you is empty.

You sit alone in the café, surrounded by frozen patrons. The grief is real and immediate—you've lost her twice now. But there's also relief. She's not suffering anymore.

choices.label: Mourn, then move forward. Build a new life.
Sit here forever. Let grief freeze you too.

nodes.title: Learning to Let Go
nodes.text:
You let yourself mourn properly. You sit in the café and remember Aline—the real one, not the painted ghost. You remember her laugh, her warmth, her courage. You let yourself feel the loss fully.

Then, slowly, you stand. You leave the café.

The Gallery awaits. You have a life to build here, different from the one you imagined, but real nonetheless.

You find the painted child by the fountain. "Can I stay with you for a while?" you ask.

"Of course."

You begin building something new. Not a replacement for what you lost, but an addition. New connections, new purposes, new hopes.

The grief doesn't disappear, but it becomes part of your landscape rather than your entire world. You carry it alongside other emotions—joy, curiosity, contentment.

choices.label: Build a community here. Help others who arrive lost.
Explore the Gallery fully. Discover everything it offers.
Seek the Canvas Ghost. You're ready now.

nodes.text:
You realize your purpose: to help others who arrive in the Gallery lost, afraid, and confused—exactly as you once were.

You establish a sanctuary near the fountain—a safe place where newly painted beings can adjust to their transformation. You teach them about their changed nature with patience. You show them their options without pushing. You help them grieve what they've lost while gently discovering what they've gained.

The painted child helps you, guiding newcomers through the fountain's mysteries. Renoir assists, offering wisdom from centuries of observation. Even the Paintress contributes occasionally, painting resources into existence for your sanctuary—furniture that comforts, walls that listen, windows showing whatever view the viewer needs.

Over time, you deliberately hollow yourself out—not fading into background, but actively becoming a vessel for others' needs. You make space inside yourself for their grief, their questions, their transformations. Each person you help carves out a little more room in you.

You become known as the Hollow Canvas—the one who has emptied themselves to hold others. Painted beings seek you out when they need guidance, comfort, understanding. You listen without judgment. You hold their pain without flinching. You become the container for their processing.

It's exhausting work—each person's trauma, each person's loss, each person's confusion takes a toll. But it's also deeply fulfilling. Each being you help fills the hollow place inside you temporarily with purpose, with meaning, with the knowledge that your suffering wasn't pointless.

You've transformed your loss into service. Your pain into compassion. Your confusion into wisdom that helps others navigate what you barely survived.

And in helping others navigate the threshold between real and painted, you've finally found your place on that threshold—not as someone still crossing, but as someone who guides others across.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: The Hollow Canvas**
*You deliberately hollowed yourself to become a vessel for others' pain and transformation. You created a sanctuary where newly painted beings learn to navigate their new existence, finding purpose in service.*

nodes.title: Challenging the Threshold
nodes.text:
"Or," you say boldly, "let me take your place. You've existed in the threshold for how long? Centuries? Millennia? Perhaps it's time for a successor."

The Canvas Ghost's formshifts—surprise? Amusement? Anger? It's impossible to read.

"You wish to replace me. Become the new Canvas Ghost."

"I'm already half-ghost. Half-real, half-painted. I exist in threshold by nature. Why not make it official?"

The Ghost circles you, considering. "Very well. A challenge. If you can exist purely in threshold for one full cycle—neither eating, nor sleeping, nor touching anything fully real or fully painted—then I will yield my position."

"And if I fail?"

"Then you will be mine. Another curiosity for my collection."

You accept.

choices.label: Begin the threshold challenge.
This is foolish. Withdraw the challenge.

nodes.text:
You attempt the threshold challenge. For one full cycle, you must exist purely between states—neither real nor painted, neither here nor there, touching nothing fully.

It's excruciating from the first moment. Your body desperately wants to commit to one state or the other. Your painted portions try to solidify into permanent pigment. Your flesh portions try to assert their reality, to be corporeal again.

You die. The first time, it's your flesh portion that fails—leaning too far toward real. It burns away like paper in flame. Then your painted portion tries to compensate, leans too far toward pigment, and shatters like glass.

The Canvas Ghost reconstitutes you from pure threshold energy. "Try again."

You die again. And again. And again. Each time you lean too far in either direction, that part of you dies catastrophically and must be rebuilt from the threshold itself.

You become a phoenix of pigment and possibility—dying and resurrecting endlessly in a brutal cycle. Each death teaches you incrementally more about balance, about existing in the razor-thin space between states. Each resurrection makes you slightly better at it.

The cycle completes after what feels like centuries but might be hours. You've died and been reborn hundreds of times. You're utterly exhausted, profoundly transformed, completely different from the being who started this trial.

The Canvas Ghost bows deeply, showing respect for the first time. "You have succeeded. Not by maintaining static existence as I expected, but by learning to die and resurrect at will. You've become something I never was, something I never imagined—a phoenix of the threshold."

"So I take your place?" you gasp, still recovering from the final death-rebirth cycle.

"No. You've earned something far better. You've become your own kind of threshold being. Not a Ghost like me, but a Phoenix. You exist through transformation itself—dying into paint, resurrecting into flesh, endlessly cycling between states. I maintain the threshold through static presence. You maintain it through constant death and rebirth."

You spread your arms experimentally and feel yourself dissolve into pure threshold energy, then reconstitute in a burst of pigment and flesh. Again. And again. You can do it at will now, die and be reborn in seconds.

You are death and rebirth. You are the cycle itself. You are the Pigment Phoenix, and you will burn and rise forever.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: Pigment Phoenix**
*You challenged the Canvas Ghost and survived through hundreds of deaths. You became the Pigment Phoenix—endlessly dying and resurrecting, existing as pure transformation, maintaining the threshold through constant rebirth.*

nodes.title: Walking the Memory Paths
nodes.text:
You thank the child but decline her offer to meet the Paintress. Instead, you wander the Gallery collecting forgotten memories on your own terms.

You become a collector, a preserver. You touch the climbing fountain waters regularly, absorbing more and more forgotten moments. You visit the café and collect the frozen patrons' suspended memories. You explore hidden corners of the Gallery where old memories settle like dust.

Each memory adds to your complexity. You become a walking archive of forgotten things—loves lost, dreams abandoned, moments that slipped through reality's cracks.

Painted beings begin seeking you out. "You knew my grandmother," one says, recognizing a memory you carry. "Tell me about her."

You do. You give people back their forgotten histories, their erased moments, their lost connections.

choices.label: Dedicate yourself to preserving and sharing forgotten memories.
The memories are overwhelming. You're losing yourself.

nodes.text:
You embrace your role as keeper of forgotten memories. You learn to organize them meticulously, catalog them by emotion and subject, access them deliberately rather than drowning in their chaotic flood.

You discover something profound and fascinating: memories of the past and memories of the future feel identical when suspended in the fountain's waters. Both are forgotten—one by time that has passed, one by time that hasn't yet arrived. The difference is merely temporal direction.

You begin to see futures through this strange symmetry. Not certain futures, but possible ones. You can touch a painted being and sense the memories they'll forget tomorrow, next year, in a century. You can see the paths they might walk by seeing what they'll lose along each path.

You become the Pigment Prophet—the one who sees through the medium of forgotten things, who reads time by its absences. Painted beings consult you before making major choices. "What will I forget if I take this path?" they ask, terrified and hopeful.

You show them honestly. If they choose love, they'll forget their solitude—the peace of being alone will become incomprehensible to them. If they choose power, they'll forget gentleness—it will seem weak rather than kind. Every choice has its forgotten cost.

Sometimes they choose the path anyway, willing to pay the price of forgotten alternatives. Sometimes they choose differently, preserving what they fear to lose.

You've become an essential guide through time's landscape, using memory—both past and future—as your map. The past and future both live in you simultaneously, forgotten and not-yet-remembered existing side by side in your vast internal archive.

The Paintress calls you her oracle, consulting you before major creative works. "What will the Gallery forget if I paint this?"

Renoir calls you the living archive, the keeper of everything that was and will be lost.

The Canvas Ghost calls you its temporal counterpart—it exists in spatial threshold, you exist in temporal threshold.

You call yourself simply the Keeper: the one who holds what everyone else has lost or will lose, preserving all forgotten things in your endless memory.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: Pigment Prophet**
*You became keeper of all forgotten memories—past and future both. You learned to see possible futures through what will be forgotten, guiding others by showing them the costs of their choices. You are the Gallery's oracle and its comprehensive memory of all that's lost.*

nodes.title: Rejecting the Forgotten
nodes.text:
You focus on expelling the foreign memories. They're not yours. You won't carry other people's forgetting.

It's difficult—the memories cling, wanting to be remembered. But you push them out, one by one, returning them to the fountain's waters.

When you're done, you feel lighter. More yourself. The painted child looks disappointed.

"You could have helped so many people," she says.

"That's not my purpose. I need to find my own path, not carry everyone else's."

choices.label: Search for your true purpose in the Gallery.
Leave the fountain. Explore alone.

nodes.title: Seeking Meaning
nodes.text:
You wander the Gallery asking yourself: Why am I here? What should I become?

You're not like Renoir, who maintains. Not like the Paintress, who creates. Not like the Canvas Ghost, who observes. You're something else. Something still undefined.

Maybe that's your strength—you haven't settled into a role yet. You're still becoming.

You experiment with different purposes. You try creating (you're okay at it). You try maintaining (it's satisfying but not quite right). You try observing (too passive for your nature).

Finally, you realize: maybe you don't need one purpose. Maybe you can be multiple things, shift between roles, refuse to be pinned down.

choices.label: Embrace being undefined. Become everything and nothing.
Keep searching. There must be one true purpose.

nodes.text:
You stop searching for a single purpose. Instead, you embrace radical multiplicity. You become the Gallery's undefined element—sometimes curator, sometimes creator, sometimes observer, sometimes rebel, always changing.

You shift roles daily, hourly even. One morning you help Renoir maintain the streets with patient precision. By afternoon you're painting alongside the Paintress, creating new impossibilities. Evening finds you simply existing, watching painted beings live their lives without intervention. Night sees you questioning the whole system, considering rebellion.

This fluidity confuses some. "What are you?" they ask, needing to categorize you.

"I'm still becoming," you answer honestly. "I might always be becoming. I might never settle into one thing. And that's enough. That's actually perfect."

You are the Living Question—the being who refuses to be answered, defined, pinned down. Every painted entity in the Gallery has eventually settled into some defined state, accepted some role. Not you. You remain perpetually transforming, perpetually choosing, perpetually becoming something new each day.

It's exhausting being undefined. It's exhilarating having infinite options. It's terrifying never knowing what you'll be tomorrow. It's exactly what you need—the freedom to never stop changing.

The Canvas Ghost observes you with something like envy. "To still be changing after all this time. I've been static for so long—the same threshold guardian, century after century—I've forgotten what transformation even feels like."

You smile, currently rendered in watercolor but shifting toward charcoal even as you speak. "It feels like this: uncertain, exciting, terrifying, free. It feels like being alive instead of preserved."

You are the Gallery's only truly undefined element. Everyone else has an answer. You remain pure question. And that's your purpose—to prove that not everything needs to be answered.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: The Living Question**
*You refused all single purposes, embracing radical multiplicity. You remain forever in flux—the Gallery's living question that refuses to be answered, perpetually transforming, eternally becoming.*

You realize your half-painted nature gives you a unique gift: you can learn and adopt any artistic style you encounter, becoming a living canvas for all of art history.

You study the Gallery obsessively, traveling through every district. Impressionist quarters where light dissolves into shimmering color. Cubist zones where perspective fractures into impossible angles. Abstract realms where form itself becomes optional, meaning over representation. Hyperrealist sections so meticulously detailed they're somehow more real than reality itself.

Each style you master becomes part of you, added to your growing repertoire. You learn to shift between them at will—one moment you're rendered in gentle watercolor, soft and bleeding at the edges. The next you're bold expressionist strokes, all passion and movement. Then photorealistic, every pore and hair visible. Then sketched in charcoal, all shadow and suggestion.

The Paintress watches your development with fascination and pride. "You've become something I never imagined possible. Not a painting fixed in one style, but a living anthology of all artistic traditions. You're art history made flesh... made paint... made whatever you choose."

Painted beings seek you out for transformation. "Make me impressionist," one requests, tired of their sharp-edged cubist existence. "I want to be softer, less defined, more about feeling than form." You paint them anew with practiced skill.

Another asks for surrealism. "I want to melt. I want to be impossible." You oblige, giving them Dalí's liquid forms.

You become the Style Shifter—the Gallery's transformer, able to reinterpret any painted being in any artistic tradition. You contain Rembrandt's chiaroscuro, Monet's shimmering light, Picasso's radical fracture, Dalí's impossible dream, Rothko's emotional color fields, Pollock's chaotic energy—all contained in one constantly metamorphosing form.

When you look at your hands, they're never the same twice. Sometimes Renaissance clarity. Sometimes post-modern deconstruction. Sometimes styles that haven't been invented yet, emerging from your unique synthesis.

That's exactly how you want it—to be every style and no style, to contain all of art's history and its future simultaneously.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: The Style Shifter**
*You mastered every artistic style in existence, becoming a living anthology of art history who shifts forms at will. You are all techniques, all traditions, constantly metamorphosing between every way art has ever been made.*

You make a choice that surprises even yourself: you will become the Gallery's historian. Its witness. Its living memory.

You position yourself in the central plaza where you can observe everything—every street, every building, every painted soul passing through. You don't intervene in what you see, don't participate in the Gallery's dramas—you simply watch and remember with perfect clarity.

Centuries pass. You document it all in your crystalline memory. The Paintress's creative phases—her periods of manic production followed by contemplative silence. Renoir's subtle changes as it slowly evolves over millennia. The endless parade of newly painted beings who arrive frightened, transform gradually, and settle into their various fates. The Canvas Ghost's rare public appearances, each one significant. The slow architectural evolution of the Gallery itself as it grows and shifts.

Your memory becomes perfect, absolute, crystalline. You forget nothing. Every painted being who ever existed in the Gallery lives on in your recollection—their faces, their stories, their transformations, their endings. You are a library of lives.

Eventually, painted beings come to you with questions about the Gallery's past. "Was there ever a district where music was visible?" Yes—District Seventeen, created in the Paintress's experimental phase, later dissolved. "Did the fountain always run backwards?" No—it ran normally for the first three centuries before the Paintress inverted it. "What was the Gallery like before?" Smaller, darker, less certain of itself.

You answer everything. You are the living history, the eternal witness, the Gallery's collective memory given form.

The Paintress visits you once per century, consulting your memories. "You've become more valuable than any of my deliberate creations," she admits. "You're the Gallery's memory externalized. Without you, we'd have no history. Just an eternal present with no context, no growth, no understanding of how we became what we are."

You continue watching. Recording. Remembering. Time flows past you like paint dissolving in water, and you capture every swirl, every color, every moment—preserving it all in your infinite internal archive.

You are eternal. You are witness. You are the Gallery's conscience and its comprehensive memory. Nothing is lost while you watch.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: Eternal Witness**
*You became the Gallery's immortal historian with perfect memory. You document every moment, preserve every story, serve as living memory for all painted existence. Nothing is forgotten while you witness.*

You discover something the Paintress never intended, something forbidden: paint can be consumed directly, and doing so grants terrible power.

It starts accidentally. You touch a wet brushstroke on a newly painted wall and some transfers to your lips. You taste it without thinking—sharp, electric, impossible. The effect is immediate and overwhelming: a rush of creative energy, a flood of possibility, a moment where you feel you could reshape yourself completely, reshape anything.

You do it again deliberately. And again. And again.

You begin drinking paint compulsively. You discover each color has wildly different effects: Blue brings calm, controlled transformation. Red ignites passionate, chaotic change. Yellow accelerates your thoughts to painful, brilliant speeds. Black offers temporary oblivion followed by violent rebirth. Green makes you grow. Purple makes you fade. White erases. Black creates.

The more you consume, the more powerful you become. You can paint new realities with a thought, no brush required. Reshape painted beings with a word. Create entire districts from pure imagination, materializing your visions.

But there's a terrible cost you didn't anticipate. You're addicted now, craving paint constantly. Your form becomes profoundly unstable—sometimes you're barely there, just a sketch threatening to blow away. Other times you're too solid, too real, painfully, overwhelmingly present.

The Paintress tries to intervene, tries to stop you. "You're consuming the Gallery itself. You're drinking the walls, the streets, the other painted beings. You'll destroy everything, including yourself."

But you can't stop. Won't stop. The power is too intoxicating, the rush too perfect. Each time you drink paint, you feel like a god. Each time you come down, you feel like nothing.

You've become the Paint Drinker—the Gallery's most dangerous addict and its most powerful inhabitant. You create magnificent works between craving fits, reshaping reality in brilliant creative bursts before collapsing into desperate need. You've painted seventeen new districts in moments of inspiration, then nearly destroyed them in withdrawal-induced rage.

You are creation and destruction intertwined. Genius and addiction inseparable. Absolute power purchased at the price of stability, sanity, and self.

The other painted beings fear you. Even the Paintress keeps her distance now. You are what happens when the boundary between creator and creation dissolves entirely—and it's both magnificent and horrifying.

**Chapter 1: Complete**
**Ending Unlocked: The Paint Drinker**
*You discovered the forbidden power of consuming paint directly. You became addicted, wielding god-like creative power in brilliant bursts while losing all stability. You are the Gallery's most dangerous and powerful being—genius and addict inseparable.*
